div.head: To Maister Arthur Hopton.
div.l: PYthagoras in teaching did maintaine,
When bodies di • de, their soules returnd againe,
And kept the minds that they were vs'de to doe,
Within those bodies they did run into:
And now I see his maxim true and iust,
Hath ben too long abused by the most:
For who shall with Iudicial eye ore-looke
The curious art composed in this Booke,
Cannot deny in Hopton to arise,
The soule of great Archimedes the wise.
Sweete Arthur, well deserust that princely name,
Which from the regall constellation came,
Arcturus bright, which in himselfe containes,
The very nature that in thee remaines.
And doubtlesse at thy blessed birth so shone,
That all the starres were dimd by him alone,
Whilst he about the Northen pole did glide,
As Lord comander of the heauens wide,
Distilling downe vpon thee without spare,
Ioues diuine nature and the God of warre:
As thou by wisdome mighst thy fame maintaine,
So well as with the honour of thy name,
Which hath ben long and ancient without doubt:
Witnesse the house from whence thou camest out,
And from whence each best Hopton of old time
By law of armes ought to deriue their line.
Then what apt ornament is't I might chuse
To feed the height of thy aspiring muse?
A crowne of bayes for Poets, not for thee,
Thy Temples scorne to beare Apollos tree:
A weath of starres, robes of immortall fame,
shall girte thy browes, shall clothe thy loued name.
